user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_strx_to_uint32_n_:
```c
size_t
MHD_strx_to_uint32_n_ (const char *str,
                       size_t maxlen,
                       uint32_t *out_val)
{
  size_t i;
  uint32_t res;
  int digit;
  if (! str || ! out_val)
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  while (i < maxlen && (digit = toxdigitvalue (str[i])) >= 0)
  {
    if ( (res > (UINT32_MAX / 16)) ||
         ((res == (UINT32_MAX / 16)) &&
          ( (uint32_t) digit > (UINT32_MAX % 16)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 16;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  }

  if (i)
    *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided function. Specifically:
- Standard fixed-width and standard types are used (uint32_t, size_t) and the macro UINT32_MAX is from standard headers (stdint.h/limits). These are not compiler extensions.
- All syntax constructs (function definition, while loop, if, casts, integer arithmetic, return) are standard C and do not rely on any vendor-specific keywords or built-ins.
- There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as GCC/Clang built-ins or attributes (__attribute__, __builtin_*, typeof, __extension__, __asm__, statement expressions ({ ... }), nested functions), Microsoft-specific keywords, or other non-standard tokens.
- The identifier toxdigitvalue() appears to be a user-defined function or macro; its presence is not itself a language extension. If that helper uses compiler extensions, that would need inspection in its own definition, but within this function its use is a plain call and not an extension.

Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that should be flagged for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions).
